Document_Content: urn:contentItem:4580-5MD0-0197-50PY-00000-00<published>1999-08-06T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:26:27Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>WORLD; Pg. 6</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Forest fire ire rising in Asia</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>IAN STEWART * Kuala Lumpur</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">SMOKE haze from forest fires in Indonesia is imposing new strains on relations among members of the Association of South-East Asian Nations just two weeks after their foreign ministers pledged to strengthen unity and co-operation.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> The threat of a repeat of the haze crisis of 1997 prompted Malaysia, Singapore and Brunei, which is hosting the South-East Asian Games next week, to express serious concern to Jakarta and call on it to intensify efforts to handle the problem.</p><p>Malaysian Environment Minister Law Hieng Ding said Indonesia had taken note of their concern and promised to take "the necessary action".</p><p>Indonesia has been making promises since its neighbours first protested about the annual haze several years ago. In 1997, thick smog blanketed much of the region, disrupting flights, slowing ships in the Malacca Strait and causing a sharp rise in respiratory ailments.</p><p> At a meeting in Singapore last month, ASEAN foreign ministers expressed support for the efforts of a special taskforce to prevent the haze. But farmers and loggers have ignored Indonesian bans on burning to clear land in Kalimantan and Sumatra.</p><p> Mr Law said a planned ASEAN meeting on haze might be brought forward from October.</p><p> So far, according to official reports in Singapore and Malaysia, the air quality in both countries has remained moderate although in Kuala Lumpur over the past two days the haze, which carries the distinctive odour of smoke from a forest fire, has been strong enough to irritate throats and noses.</p><p> Mr Law said the Malaysian Government had decided against "overly publicising" the readings in order "not to drive away the tourists".</p><p> Reports from Jakarta said smoke from scrub and forest fires was thickening across Sumatra and Kalimantan. Pollution in Sumatra's Riau Province had soared to dangerous levels.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:5P5G-C8X1-F0J6-J330-00000-00Summer firefighting recruitment opens2017-08-04T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:26:27ZLexisNexisSummer firefighting recruitment opensJohn Chanter

Forest Fire Management Victoria has begun recruiting project firefighters and new permanent forest and fire operations officers across the state to help keep people safe this fire season.

"Statewide, there are 300 project firefighters positions available along with 49 new permanent forest and fire operations officer roles," Hume acting assistant chief fire officer Shaun Lawlor said.

For more information and to apply online, visit www.ffm.vic.gov.au or phone 136 186.

Project firefighters, and forest and fire operations officers, respond to bushfires and other emergencies, help deliver the planned burning program and undertake a variety of fire preparedness activities including road, track and firebreak maintenance.

"Advertising commenced this week for project firefighters and 15 permanent forest and fire operations officers in the Hume region," Mr Lawler said.

"These forest firefighters are an important addition to our resources as we prepare for the upcoming fire season.

"This fire season, Forest Fire Management Victoria will have over 1000 forest firefighters, supported by a further 2000 staff from across DELWP, Parks Victoria, Melbourne Water and VicForests, who have a fire role in addition to their normal duties."

They also assist with the ongoing maintenance and improvement of forest recreation sites, pest and weed control works, and other forest management activities.

These jobs will be based at Department of Environment, Land, Water and Planning (DELWP) and Parks Victoria offices and depots in regional Victoria.

This summer, Forest Fire Management Victoria ran a video project to follow around eight Project Firefighters across the state to capture their experience behind the scenes.

urn:contentItem:5VMJ-PCY1-JBJ7-N0V7-00000-00'It's quite disgusting': Steel spikes hidden on off-road tracks in Victorian bushland2019-03-13T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:26:27ZLexisNexis'It's quite disgusting': Steel spikes hidden on off-road tracks in Victorian bushlandSimone Fox Koob

Thick steel spikes have been found hidden on tracks used by emergency services, including firefighters.

A number of steel spikes have been discovered hidden on tracks in bushland north-east of Melbourne, angering locals and emergency services who labelled the behaviour "reckless and dangerous".

Police are investigating after the steel spikes, more than 10 centimetres long, were found concealed under leaves and bark on the Breakoday Track in the Toolangi State Forest.

Mason Friedl, a carpenter, was camping in the forest over the Labour Day long weekend when two new tyres on the driver's side of his vehicle were punctured.

When he got out of the car to have a look, he found two thick metal spikes which had been hidden under leaves along a 20-metre stretch of the road. Mr Friedl later found two other spikes a short distance away.

"It was the second day into the trip when we ran over the spikes and that cut it pretty short," he said.

"I found the first two, I got out and thought it must have been a stick but then I saw one in the ground and saw another right behind me and thought 'what's going on here?'

"My main concern about the whole thing is it's dangerous for everyone out there. If there's a bushfire going there, and a truck is grounded for something like this, it won't make it out. "

He said he was also worried there may be more spikes in the area.

The discovery has also sparked concern from emergency services because the tracks are managed by Forest Fire Management and are designed for use by fire trucks and other vehicles.

"This reckless and dangerous behaviour poses a significant threat to members of the community who legitimately use forest roads for recreational activities, including four-wheel driving, trail-bike riding and horse riding," said Aaron Kennedy, assistant chief fire officer for Forest Fire Management Victoria's Hume region.

"It also threatens the safety of our staff as they continue to respond to bushfires and undertake forest management activities."

Mr Kennedy said Forest Fire Management Victoria took the threat to community and staff safety seriously, and were working with Victoria Police to investigate.

Wayne Heavey, the chief executive of Four Wheel Drive Victoria, also labelled the behaviour as irresponsible.

"Tyres puncturing is the least impact we can see. Someone riding a horse, or motorbike - it could impale them. It's just not good from anyone's point of view," he said.

"The main reason the tracks are there is for emergency vehicle access ... It makes their job, which is hard enough any day of the week, almost impossible.

"Imagine running down the track to help save someone's property, all of a sudden - bang, bang and the truck can't move. It's ridiculous, nonsensical and stupid."

He said it wasn't the first time the steel spikes had been found.

"There have been instances in Toolangi before, in the last four or five years. In one case it was sharpened star pickets planted in a mud hole."

A police spokesman said the incident was being investigated after a report of criminal damage.

"Police have been told that a vehicle sustained two punctured tyres after driving over several spikes intentionally left on a track in the forest on Friday, 8 March," he said.

Anyone with information is urged to contact Crime Stoppers on 1800 333 000.

urn:contentItem:5M7Y-HBG1-JD34-V08X-00000-00Planned burns in central Victoria2016-11-26T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:26:27ZLexisNexisPlanned burns in central Victoria

Authorities are intending to conduct planned burns in the Heathcote, Wedderburn, Maryborough, Avoca, Bendigo and Rushworth areas.

Forest Fire Management Victoria and CFA have advised that the following planned burning will be carried out from Sunday, weather conditions permitting:

These burns should be completed between 10am on Sunday and 6pm on Wednesday.

Further planned burns will be carried out in and around Heathcote from Monday, weather conditions permitting:

These burns should be completed between 10am on Monday and 6pm on Wednesday.

Forest Fire Management Victoria Murray Goldfields District Manager, Paul Bates, said Remote Piloted Aircraft System (RPAS) would be used for the first time by Forest Fire Management Victoria firefighters at Sunday's burns.

Authorities said residents might be affected by smoke from these planned burns and smoke may be visible from nearby localities and communities.

"We ask that if people see smoke and are concerned, they ring the VicEmergency Hotline, not 000," Mr Bates said.

"It is important 000 is only used in case of emergency if you see flames.

"We understand that smoke from planned burns may cause concern for some people, but it's important we take the opportunity while conditions are right, so we can reduce bushfire risk for communities."

"Forest Fire Management Victoria work with the Bureau of Meteorology and will only do planned burns when conditions such as humidity, temperature and wind speed are right."

People experiencing symptoms that may be due to smoke exposure should seek medical advice or call NURSE-ON-CALL on 1300 60 60 24.

To stay up to date on when and where planned burns are happening near you, go to vic.gov.au/plannedburn, download the VicEmergency App or call the VicEmergency Hotline on 1800 226 226.

Visit the DELWP website for more information on the Victorian Government's new approach to bushfire risk management.

Authorities are intending to conduct planned burns in the Heathcote, Wedderburn, Maryborough, Avoca, Bendigo and Rushworth areas.

Forest Fire Management Victoria and CFA have advised that the following planned burning will be carried out from Sunday, weather conditions permitting:

These burns should be completed between 10am on Sunday and 6pm on Wednesday.

Further planned burns will be carried out in and around Heathcote from Monday, weather conditions permitting:

These burns should be completed between 10am on Monday and 6pm on Wednesday.

Forest Fire Management Victoria Murray Goldfields District Manager, Paul Bates, said Remote Piloted Aircraft System (RPAS) would be used for the first time by Forest Fire Management Victoria firefighters at Sunday's burns.

Authorities said residents might be affected by smoke from these planned burns and smoke may be visible from nearby localities and communities.

"We ask that if people see smoke and are concerned, they ring the VicEmergency Hotline, not 000," Mr Bates said.

"It is important 000 is only used in case of emergency if you see flames.

"We understand that smoke from planned burns may cause concern for some people, but it's important we take the opportunity while conditions are right, so we can reduce bushfire risk for communities."

"Forest Fire Management Victoria work with the Bureau of Meteorology and will only do planned burns when conditions such as humidity, temperature and wind speed are right."

People experiencing symptoms that may be due to smoke exposure should seek medical advice or call NURSE-ON-CALL on 1300 60 60 24.

To stay up to date on when and where planned burns are happening near you, go to vic.gov.au/plannedburn, download the VicEmergency App or call the VicEmergency Hotline on 1800 226 226.

Visit the DELWP website for more information on the Victorian Government's new approach to bushfire risk management.

urn:contentItem:5S1R-71T1-JD34-V4V6-00000-00What a difference a day makes2018-04-06T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:26:27ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 5What a difference a day makesGreg Gliddon

AS a brilliant sunset gave way to fog and mist, Ballarat residents are being told to expect more of the same on the weekend.

With little to no wind forecast until Sunday, locals can expect foggy mornings and a smoke haze due to ongoing burn offs throughout the region.

And the stable conditions will mean planned burn offs will continue over the coming weeks.

District Manager Midlands District from Forest Fire Management Victoria Jasmine Filmer said In the past two weeks Forest Fire Management Victoria has undertaken planned burning in the Midlands District in three locations; within the Enfield State Forest, within the Wombat Forest area near Blackwood, Trentham, Newbury and Lyonville and near Greendale.

While Forest Fire Management Victoria has completed its current set of burn offs, other coordinated "stubble burnings" will continue today and over the weekend.

"With warmer weather forecast, there will not be any further ignitions occurring over this weekend. Our focus will be on patrolling existing burn sites," Ms Filmer said.

"We have been advised of multiple permits issued for stubble burns occurring across the Ballarat area including at Burrumbeet, Windermere, Cardigan, Ercildoune, Ascot, Blowhard, Addington, Weatherboard, Waubra, Smeaton, Dean and Newlyn.

"Many of these permit holders have multiple blocks to burn ranging from small acreage to 150 hectares."

Bureau of Meteorology duty forecaster Dean Stewart said Ballarat is set for more of the same until Sunday when a northerly wind is expected to blow through.

"We would expect similar conditions for the next couple of days, but there might be a bit of southerly breeze on Saturday afternoon," he said. "On Sunday, Ballarat can expect a northerly breeze to come through which should help disperse the smoke.

"At this stage, it looks like conditions will remain stable with no rain forecast in the district until Thursday."

Mr Stewart said the western half of Victoria could expect a close to normal winter, with slightly more rain expected in the east.

"Our climate modelling outlook shows a 50-50 split in terms of weather throughout winter," he said.

To find out more information about the planned burns expected over the next 10 days in your area, go to ffm.vic.gov.au

urn:contentItem:6GSP-55H3-RS94-52JK-00000-00September 18, 2025: Autonomous University of Barcelona Horses: Emerging Players in Forest Fire Prevention2025-09-20T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:26:28ZLexisNexisANNOUNCEMENTSSeptember 18, 2025: Autonomous University of Barcelona Horses: Emerging Players in Forest Fire Prevention

A collaborative study involving Boumort Wildland, the Miranda Foundation, the Forest Horses association, and the University of Barcelona (UB) demonstrates that horses can adapt their diets based on breed, environment, and usage. This adaptability positions them as complementary allies alongside other herbivores in sustainable fire prevention initiatives, as their grazing reduces fuel loads and preserves open landscapes. The research was co-authored by UAB's Department of Animal and Food Science researchers Jordi Bartolome and Araceli Gort-Esteve. "Until now research on extensive herding and forest fire prevention has focused mainly on sheep and goats, with some isolated studies done on breeds of rustic cattle. There have been very few studies on horses within this context, since traditionally they are classified as plant grazers that have little effect on woody vegetation," says Ariadna Nieto-Espinet, a Ramon y Cajal researcher at the UdL and zooarchaeologist. "Our work is one of the first to use empirical data to analyse their potential in forest management in the Mediterranean," she concludes.

urn:contentItem:5T76-T111-JD3N-50YC-00000-00Fired up already2018-09-10T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:26:27ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 13Fired up alreadyTAMARA McDONALD

PLANNING for the summer fire season, which is likely to start earlier than usual, is well underway.

Activities to prepare for the season have been brought forward, with seasonal staff also rostered on earlier.

Forest Fire Management Victoria District Manager Otways David Roberts said "the Bureau of Meteorology's forecast for a longer, drier summer for Victoria extends to the Otway District, with an El Nino watch in the current outlook".

"In response to this outlook, we have brought forward several preparedness activities, including our slashing program around the coastal communities of Anglesea, Aireys Inlet and Lorne," Mr Roberts said.

"The program creates fuel breaks, referred to as asset protection zones, between public forest and private property to provide a permanent reduced fuel area.

"This allows for greater defendable spaces for these communities in the event of a significant bushfire." He said Forest Fire Management Victoria's seasonal contracted firefighters had been brought on four weeks earlier than previous years.

He said the spring planned burn program would start when conditions were suitable, "targeting smaller strategic areas near townships".

"Our aim is to complete strategic burns around towns in the eastern and central Otways, including Anglesea, Aireys Inlet, Lorne, Forrest and Gellibrand," he said.

These burns are being jointly planned and delivered with the CFA.The Southern Australia Seasonal Bushfire Outlook indicates Victoria will have a "normal" fire season, but in East Gippsland conditions appear to be above normal.

urn:contentItem:5WW6-KRW1-JD34-V49S-00000-00'Intense but extremely fulfilling': Meet Horsham's project firefighters | Photos2019-08-23T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:26:27ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 6'Intense but extremely fulfilling': Meet Horsham's project firefighters | PhotosAlexander Darling

The hardest part of David Elliott's job comes when he has to travel.

The Dimboola-born acting forest fire operations officer has this year spent several weeks driving back and forth between the Horsham base and Gippsland in Victoria's east.

On each occasion, he has worked as part of a Wimmera task force helping to fight three separate out-of-control bushfires between January and March.

Related:

10 years since the Remlaw Fire Five years since the Northern Grampian Complex Fire "Doing those task forces week in, week out is very challenging," he said.

"We do seven-day deployments which usually involve a couple of days of travel and then five full working days where we could be on 10- to 14-hour shifts.

"It's extremely hot, you're wearing clothes that weigh you down and the terrain is steep and rocky. It's completely different to where we have to go to fight fires in the Wimmera - except for the Grampians."

Now in his ninth season with Forest Fire Management Victoria, Mr Elliott, 28, said he had gotten to know the other members of the Horsham depot well, due to the nature of their deployments.

When these happen, he has to work, travel and share bunk rooms with the same group of 20 people.

"It can be challenging if you're not used to working in big team environments, so you have to find mutual interests, work on them and get used to each other's company," he said. "There are a few blokes in the depot who have young kids and it takes a toll on them."

Mr Elliott is sharing his experiences as the Department of the Environment, Land, Water and Planning has called for more people to join them as project firefighters this season.

He said firefighting was just one part of his job.

"We also help look after state forests and national parks, maintaining tracks so vehicles have clear fire access," he said.

Mr Elliot moved to Horsham when he was 21, and became a project firefighter after beginning his working life as a laborer.

"A few years ago, I had an opportunity to do some weed spraying for Parks Victoria out at Wail over winter. They asked me if I'd be interested in doing it and I jumped at the chance," he said. "I guess the exciting bit for me was the amount of work we do with heavy machinery like bulldozers and excavators."

What followed was a month's worth of training - including a grueling fitness test at Horsham's Dudley Cornell Park at the height of summer.

"You have to run 4.8 kilometres in 45 minutes with a 20-kilogram weight vest on your back - unless you're under 68kg, then you can do it with 15kg," he said.

"That prepares you for what it's like fighting forest fires."

Safety, Support, Positivity Another Horsham depot worker, Forest Fire Operations Officer Andrew Wall, has protected national parks from fires for 23 years.

Mr Wall began his work at Rushworth in central Victoria, and has since worked in Benalla in the state's north-east, in Shepparton, Bendigo and Western Australia.

"Fire management wasn't necessarily something I wanted to do - when I was at school I wanted to be a builder," he said.

"But I was involved in the Country Fire Authority and I was kind of already doing the work involved in forest fire roles through assisting family members. Part of my role is to lead some of those task forces away to other areas of the state."

Mr Wall, who has served in the Wimmera for the past four-and-a-half years, said the biggest changes he had seen in his time were a greater emphasis on safety.

"Twenty-plus years ago we went burning where we thought we needed to. Now there's a consultation process that goes on to reduce the impact on the community," he said.

A DELWP spokeswoman confirmed there will be 21 new recruits from the Wimmera district this fire season - nine from Parks Victoria and 12 from DELWP.

Parks Victoria's manager of emergency fire and operations, Andrew Graystone, said of the nine personnel they were seeking, four would work from Halls Gap and five at Wail. Mr Wall said the new recruits would join the eight permanent staff and five long-term contracted project firefighters at the Horsham base.

"As we move into the summer, the state makes a decision on numbers based on the predicted forecast and where we're at currently," he said.

"At the moment, the Wimmera has received average rainfall, so we're not looking too bad - but in the east of the state, there has been below-average rainfall, so their dryness is high.

"During the fire season, if it's 43 degrees and 45 kilometre-an-hour winds we obviously won't be out in the bush doing maintenance.

"Most of those days, in the mid-afternoon, I'll call the guys back to the base and we'll do different training scenarios so we're ready for an emergency response. We also have to be ready to help during floods and storms."

Mr Wall said the preparedness involved focusing on depot values.

"Things like integrity, honesty, being supportive, communication and safety. We talk about them often so that gets instilled within the group and when they're away they can be challenged and tested," he said.

Mr Wall summed up a forest firefighter's job as "intense but extremely fulfilling".

Mr Elliott agreed.

"I get a big kick out of working in a team environment and trying to do some good around the Wimmera district - it's really rewarding in that sense," he said.

While you're with us, you can now receive updates straight to your inbox twice weekly from the Wimmera Mail-Times. To make sure you're up-to-date with all the news from across the Wimmera, sign up below.

urn:contentItem:3RNX-SS30-0048-T14T-00000-00<published>1998-01-02T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:26:27Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>Nationwide General News; Australian General News</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>VIC: EAST VICTORIAN FOREST FIRE STILL OUT OF CONTROL</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">MELBOURNE, Jan 2 AAP - A vast fire which has burned out more than 5,000 hectares of forest in east Victoria's Alpine National Park could take several days to bring under control, firefighters said today.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Department of Natural Resources and Environment State Fire Co-ordinator Fabian Crowe said a team of more than 600 firefighters drawn from across the state would fight to control the fast-moving fire, with firebombing to resume this morning.</p><p>"It has the potential to burn over many thousands of hectares, over three or four days," Mr Crowe said.</p><p> "We're not winning this at all."</p><p> Burning embers were starting spot fires up to five kilometres ahead of the main fire, and steep and heavily forested terrain was hampering firefighters.</p><p> The blaze, believed to have been started by a campfire left unattended on New Year's Eve, was probably the most serious Victorian forest fire since the summer of 1982-1983 when forest fires burned in the area for more than two weeks, Mr Crowe said.</p><p> Bureau of Meteorology predictions for continued heat and strong winds in the region were the "worst possible" news for firefighters, he said.</p><p> Campers have been evacuated and are urged to avoid the area.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">AAPNEW1998</dc:source><dc:identifier identifierScheme="PGUID">urn:contentItem:3RNX-SS30-0048-T14T-00000-00</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="productContentSetIdentifier">160586</dc:source><dc:date dateType="last-updated">2016-01-23</dc:date></dc:metadata><wordCount number="203"/><publicationInfo><publicationName>AAP NEWSFEED</publicationName><copyright>Copyright 1998 AAP Information Services Pty. urn:contentItem:5S4G-VDP1-JD34-V1F6-00000-00Burns planned in central Victoria to reduce bushfire risk2018-04-19T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:26:27ZLexisNexisBurns planned in central Victoria to reduce bushfire risk

BURNS are planned for Rushworth and Boort tomorrow.

A 21-hectare burn will take place in Rushworth State Forest at McDonald Street.

Forest Fire Management Victoria and Dja Dja Wurrung will also undertake a six-hectare ecological planned burn at Little Lake Boort.

Smaller burns are planned for both Maldon and White Hills on Friday, clearing about 16 hectares each.

Forest Fire Management Victoria Murray Goldfields district manager, Paul Bates said the burns were part of an integrated plan to reduce bushfire risk to people, property and valued assets.

"We will only undertake planned burning when the weather conditions - such as humidity, temperature and wind speed - are assessed as suitable so plans can change at short notice.

"We understand that smoke from planned burns may cause concern for some people, but it's important that experienced fire crews take the opportunity while conditions are right so we can reduce bushfire risk for communities.

He suggested that people experiencing symptoms related to smoke exposure seek medical advice or call NURSE-ON-CALL on 1300 60 60 24.

To keep up-to-date on burns planned for the next 10 days in your area, go to www.ffm.vic.gov.au/plannedburn or download the VicEmergency app.

urn:contentItem:51MV-1871-JCVT-J4CV-00000-00Netanyahu criticised over lack of preparedness for forest fire2010-12-07T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:26:27ZLexisNexisNEWS AND FEATURESInternational NewsPg. 8Netanyahu criticised over lack of preparedness for forest fireJason Koutsoukis HERALD CORRESPONDENT

JERUSALEM: As firefighters finally extinguished the worst forest fire in Israel's history, which left 41 people dead, the political fight over who to blame for the disaster was only just beginning. With most Israeli commentators savagely critical of the country's lack of firefighting preparedness, the Prime Minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, was forced onto the defensive. "It must be understood that massive forest fires are fundamentally different from routine fires," Mr Netanyahu said after a special cabinet meeting.

Israel was unashamed at having to request international assistance to fight the fires, as had other countries, including Russia, Ukraine and the US, when faced with out-of-control forest fires, he said. "The issue of closing the gaps in the conventional, ground-based - not aerial - firefighting network is an important issue," Mr Netanyahu said. "The government has begun to deal with this issue, which has demanded a solution for 62 years. We have started to deal with it." Writing in the daily Haaretz, commentator Amir Oren said the fires were "Netanyahu's Katrina", a reference toGeorge Bush's much criticised handling of the hurricane that devastated New Orleans in 2005, while he was US president. "The politicians passed themselves off as purposeful responders to 3am phone calls. In reality they didn't have a clue as to what to do when the phone rang at 3pm," Oren wrote. Analyst Alex Fishman wrote in the daily Yedioth Ahronoth that the fires undermined Israel's national security. "On Thursday, we saw a pathetic government attempt to cope with this unforgivable failure. We deserve security, but we don't have it," Fishman wrote. Rabbi Ovadia Yossef, the politically influential spiritual leader of the ultra-orthodox Jewish party Shas, said there was little doubt that the fires were sent by God to punish those Israelis who did not observe the Sabbath. In his weekly sermon, Rabbi Yossef quoted a section from the Talmud that proclaimed that "the fire only exists in a place where the Sabbath is desecrated". "Homes were ruined, entire neighbourhoods wiped out, and it's not arbitrary," he said. "It is all divine providence. We must repent and keep the Sabbath properly." In the Palestinian territory of Gaza, the leader of the Hamas government, Ismail Haniyeh, said "those fires are divine strikes for what [Israel] did" to Gaza in the 2009 war known as Operation Cast Lead. The fire, which destroyed nearly 5000 hectares of pine forest around Mount Carmel, in northern Israel, was extinguished late on Sunday with the help of an international firefighting coalition that included teams from the European Union, Turkey, the US and Russia. An Evergreen 747 Supertanker, the world's biggest firefighting plane, was used to drop more than 40 tonnes of fire-retardant chemicals over the fire zone. Two brothers aged 14 and 15, from the Druze village of Isfiya, were arrested on Saturday on suspicion of causing the fire through negligence following a picnic.

PHOTO: Hope from above ... Benjamin Netanyahu watches a plane dropping fire-retardant chemicals on the fire at Mount Carmel. Photo: AFP/Guy Assaga

urn:contentItem:5X77-0HK1-F0J6-J3H9-00000-00Preparing for fire season2019-10-09T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:26:27ZLexisNexisPreparing for fire seasonTara Cosoleto

EMERGENCY services in central Victoria are expecting fire season conditions to be on par with other years.

Despite a warmer than average start to 2019, Forest Fire Management regional manager Paul Bates said decent rainfall throughout the region in the past few months has helped the situation.

"In central Victoria, we're expecting what we consider a normal or typical fire season," Mr Bates said.

"We've had reasonable winter rain. Forests are now starting to try out particularly as we move into late spring and summer.

"But to the north of Bendigo, there hasn't been much rain and as you go further along the Murray River - around Kerang, Cohuna, and Echuca - those areas are now very dry. Indeed, we have had some small fires up there already this season."

Country Fire Authority operations manager Bill Johnstone said the conditions would vary across the region throughout the summer.

"We've got quite some disparaging differences between the north of the district near Elmore and Goornong to right down in Gisborne where it's still a little green and a bit damp under foot," Mr Johnstone said.

"So it does vary with topography and land use."

Mr Bates said Forest Fire Management has already started planned burns this month, which was on track with previous years.

"We've been doing a lot of work," he said. "We've employed our seasonal project fire fighters and we're having a training camp in St Arnaud in two weeks time to train new people.

"But critically, we've started planned burning this week at local forests as they're starting to dry out.

"We've started a burn in Dargile and also have a burn near Tarnagulla planned. We're also working with Dja Dja Wurrung to do a couple of cultural burns in Victoria, which is really important work too."

Mr Johnston said the CFA was preparing for every possible scenario.

"We will have a summer every year," he said. "We know that. It would be good to have no campaigns and no large fires that really set ourselves and the community back. Ideally, we'd like to have nothing happen at all. But we know that that's simply not going to happen."

The community also needed to take some responsibility, Mr Johnston said.

"The message is fairly routine," he said. "Now is the time to prepare for the summer ahead. So if you need to clean up around your property, do those things.

"Check out the CFA and the DEWLP websites to understand what your responsibilities are. Understand what it is you need to do on extreme fire days.

"Basically, it's about just getting everything ready and in order because we may not be there to help you."

urn:contentItem:54MN-RWV1-F0JP-W267-00000-00Battle steps up as winds fan forest fire2012-01-04T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:26:27ZLexisNexisLOCALPg. 3Battle steps up as winds fan forest fireDAVID KILLICK

A BUSHFIRE in the state's South has flared in strong winds, causing concern for fire crews.

Forestry Tasmania firefighters were last night planning to use a bulldozer to create containment lines to help water bombing and backburning of the 34ha blaze in state forest between the Plenty and Russell valleys in the Derwent Valley.

Forestry Tasmania's Tony Blanks said the fire had picked up yesterday afternoon in 60km/h to 70km/h winds.

``It's at fairly high elevation and it's high enough that it's caught the very dry air that's in the upper reaches and it's also very exposed to the wind,'' he said.

``It's of no realistic threat to houses or private property.''

Forestry Tasmania crews are also working on a small fire in the foothills of Mt Roland.

The fire, which may have been deliberately lit, is in a recently harvested coupe between Sheffield and Gowrie Park in the North.

And a small fire was burning in dense rainforest on the Pipeline Rd, 60km south of Smithton, believed to have been caused by a lightning strike.

Tasmania Fire Service crews were also working on fires near Triabunna and in Myrtle rainforest on the West Coast.

A series of deliberately lit fires in the Ravenswood area required seven fire crews and assistance from a helicopter to bring them under control.

No properties were under threat.

urn:contentItem:58YG-9KV1-JC0X-K0SB-00000-00The Intractable Studies Institute releases seven solutions for tornado, tsunami, flood, forest fire, floating oil-platform fire, labor and world peace2013-07-23T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:26:27ZLexisNexisThe Intractable Studies Institute releases seven solutions for tornado, tsunami, flood, forest fire, floating oil-platform fire, labor and world peacePERALTA, New Mexico July 23, 2013





    The Intractable Studies Institute released solutions for the tornado,

tsunami, flood, forest fire, floating oil-platform fire, android-robot labor

and world peace.  These solutions will save lives and property.  The mission of

their Institute is to create and publish solutions initially for the top 50 of

the most intractably difficult challenges known, this completes seven.





    The importance of solutions are self-evident as the last decade has seen

hundreds of thousands of deaths from these natural and man-made disasters and

hundreds of billions of dollars in cost.  The android-robot labor solution

creates a symbiotic human-android labor pool, and has a side-effect of

obsoleting pensions, retirement savings and Social Security since a robot is

effectively all of these in the provided solution.  The importance of world

peace is self-evident.



    Each solution is a single-page PDF file at the Institute web site

http://IntractableStudiesInstitute.org, aka Intra23.org.  The solutions can be

downloaded from their site via the slide show there and the Communications menu

bar.  All seven Communications are entirely free to the public.



    The Director of the Institute had this to say about this release, "These

seven solutions will lay the groundwork for a world where natural disasters are

less tragic, people share their heavy work-load with robots, and world peace

becomes inevitable."



    Their Institute thinks outside of the box of normal researchers to create

highly innovative solutions to very difficult challenges.  The Institute itself

is outside the box of traditional research centers in that by design their

mission is to publish theoretical solutions before they are tested, and those

'Communications of the Institute' are appropriately labeled theoretical.  

Regarding this model the Director had this to say, "The Institute prefers this

model because it gets our solutions out the door faster to the public,

researchers and other entities that want and need these solutions."  



    Founded in 2013, the Intractable Studies Institute's mission is to create

solutions exclusively for intractably hard challenges.  The Institute motto is

"Think outside the box."  The company logo says it best: "When all else fails,

come to the Institute."             http://IntractableStudiesInstitute.org (Intra23.org)

    Patrick M. Rael, Director of the Intractable Studies Institute, LLC,

urn:contentItem:7VHJ-9P01-2RG7-3027-00000-00Barmah Forest fire risk 'ignored'2009-04-23T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:26:27ZLexisNexisBarmah Forest fire risk 'ignored'

Barmah residents are accusing the Victorian Government of ignoring their concerns about the fire risk in the Barmah Forest.

Cattle grazing and timber logging in the forest has been banned because of the drought and plans for a national park will permanently keep cattle out.

The River and Red Gum Environment Alliance's Peter Newman says high fuel loads in the forest pose a serious risk to the northern Victoria town.

"The community actually had to take matters [into its own hands] and break the law by putting cattle into the forest to try and protect itself," he said.

"We believe we were vindicated from that by what happened on Black Saturday.

"This is what we've been talking about for many months - they still won't listen, they don't care."

'Positive meeting'

Timber workers have been given an adjustment package as a result of the logging ban but so far the cattlemen have not received assistance.

Environment Minister Gavin Jennings yesterday met the Barmah Forest Cattlemen's Association to discuss the effect the ban will have on their farming operations but his planned visit to Barmah has been cancelled.

The association's president Kelvin Trickey says he is happy with the meeting.

"The Minister's going to go back, talk to DPI [Department of Primary Industries] and various groups to see where some help can come from," he said.

"No promises [were] made but as he said he's going to roll his sleeves up and see what's available, what's around and what they might be able to come up with."

Overseas News</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>E KALIMANTAN ASKS FOR AIRCRAFT TO CONTROL FOREST FIRE</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">ll <emphasis typeStyle="it">d</emphasis></p><p nitf:lede="true">im</p><p nitf:lede="true"><emphasis typeStyle="it"> BALIKPAPAN, Indonesia, April 1 Asia Pulse - The East Kalimantan Forestry Office has requested the use of Canadian Bombardier CL-215 and CL-415 aircraft from the central government as part of an effort to extinguish a forest fire,  <br/> the office's head, Kayat R Sutarjo, reported to Forestry Minister Sumahadi and East Kalimantan Governor H M Ardans.    Water bombing using a Pilatus aircraft was successful in<br/> Bontang and Sangatta. </emphasis></p><p> "We have tried everything we can to<br/> extinguish the fire, but the burning goes on," Kayat said.</p><p> He said it was difficult to use artificial rain, as the weather did not allow this.</p><p> Forestry Minister and East Kalimantan Governor are making an air inspection of East Kalimantan forest burning the whole Monday, particularly the Soeharto Hill, Wain River densed forest, Kutai densed forest, Bontang  and Sangatta areas.<br/></p><p> According to Head of East Kalimantan Environmental Impact Control Body, H Awang Faroek Ishak here Sunday, the area burnt had reached 148,056 ha with a loss of Rp 2.561 trillion (US$512.2 million).</p><p> According to a Suara Pembaruan daily correspondent in Balikpapan who made a three hour flight Monday over Balikpapan, Muara Badak, Bontang and  Muara Ancalong, there<br/> was a thick haze  covered a part of East Kalimantan,<br/> particularly Balikpapan, Kutai and Samarinda. In the rural area of Kelinjau river the visibility was only 200 meters.    (ANTARA)<br/></p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">AAPNEW1998</dc:source><dc:identifier identifierScheme="PGUID">urn:contentItem:3SC2-9GY0-0048-T2R6-00000-00</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="productContentSetIdentifier">160586</dc:source><dc:date dateType="last-updated">2016-01-23</dc:date></dc:metadata><wordCount number="248"/><publicationInfo><publicationName>AAP NEWSFEED</publicationName><copyright>Copyright 1998 AAP Information Services Pty. urn:contentItem:5PTH-T6K1-JD34-V34X-00000-00Planned burns for Ararat and Stawell2017-10-06T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:26:27ZLexisNexisPlanned burns for Ararat and Stawell

Forest Fire Management Victoria will soon start its Spring planned burning operations around Ararat and Stawell.

Wimmera District forest and fire operations manager Glenn Rudolph said planned burns would take place within the Ararat Hills Regional Park and Deep Lead Nature Conservation Reserve.

"We have several fuel reduction burns scheduled within the next few weeks, aimed at reducing forest fuels and the spread and intensity of bushfires potentially impacting on these two townships," he said.

"Two planned burns are located within the Ararat Hills Regional Park on the edge of Ararat township, and another within the Deep Lead Nature Conservation Reserve five kilometres north-west of Stawell.

"Residents of Ararat and surrounds may see or smell smoke from the 70-hectare One Tree Hill Track hand candling and 26-hectare Hawk Track North fuel reduction burns."

Mr Rudolph said Forest Fire Management Victoria was committed to working with communities to reduce the impacts of bushfires, through its 'Safer Together' approach.

"Burning these priority areas in Spring will avoid smoke impacts on adjoining wineries during the Autumn grape-harvesting season," he said.

"Hand candling, which involves burning the extreme bark hazard off trees, helps to reduce spotting and makes life easier for planned burn crews working to reduce fuel hazard; spot fires emanating from bushfires are a major hazard for firefighters and communities trying to defend assets.

"Residents of Deep Lead, Stawell, Concongella may similarly see or smell smoke from the Deep Lead Forty Foot Track planned burn.

"This 102ha planned burn is aimed at providing an irregular mosaic of burnt and unburnt areas to promote floristic diversity. There are known native orchid populations within this Nature Conservation Reserve, which will be deliberately excluded from burning operations."

For the latest information about when planned burns are happening go online to to www.ffm.vic.gov.au/plannedburn, download the VicEmergency smartphone app or call the VicEmergency hotline on 1800 226 226.

More about Forest Fire Management Victoria's Safer Together approach can be found at www.safer together.vic.gov.au.

urn:contentItem:5R8K-YF71-F0J6-J3N0-00000-00Campers warned to follow fire safety rules this summer2017-12-28T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:26:27ZLexisNexisCampers warned to follow fire safety rules this summerAshley Fritsch

Campers are being warned to follow the rules when it comes to lighting fires this summer.

Forest Fire Management Victoria's Tim Wishart said, since the beginning of 2017, 18 bushfires had been started by campfire negligence in central Victoria.

"This is placing the community and firefighters at risk, as well as potentially damaging the environment and affecting industry and recreational users of our public land," he said.

"It takes a lot of time, effort and personnel to respond to a fire, so when campfires escape and could have been prevented by following the rules, it's very frustrating."

A new campaign by Forest Fire Management Victoria is hoping to stop this number climbing during summer.

"We want people to get out there and enjoy themselves but make campfire safety a priority for their trip by knowing what they can and can't do," Mr Wishart said.

The warning comes after a scrub fire at Huntly earlier this month, where authorities are investigating as to whether a campfire was to blame.

The blaze burnt six hectares of public land alongside the Bendigo Creek and was being monitored by crews for days after.

Forest Fire Management Victoria senior fire management officer Jeff Wilkie said the fire occurred on a day of total fire ban, when no campfires should be lit.

Firefighters were also called to an unattended campfire at Mount Alexander days earlier.

"Campfires shouldn't be left unattended," Mr Wilkie said.

"Extinguish them with water and if it's cool to touch, then you're good to go."

People found breaching campfire safety rules can find themselves with on the spot fines of up to $476 and, if the matter is prosecuted in court, can face a maximum penalty of $15,872.

Parks Victoria fire and emergency director David Nugent said rangers regularly patrolled parks, forests and reserves to ensure campers were doing the right thing and to educate visitors on campfire safety.

"Before you head out, make sure you plan ahead and check the long-range weather forecast. If in doubt on a hot day, don't light your campfire," he said.

"It is everyone's responsibility to ensure they follow the campfire safety rules."

urn:contentItem:5S3M-YJT1-JD34-V2M1-00000-00Fire near Mount Buffalo burns 600 hectares2018-04-15T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:26:27ZLexisNexisFire near Mount Buffalo burns 600 hectaresEllen Ebsary

A fire that began in remote state forest, about 12 kilometres south of Mount Buffalo, is not yet under control.

The Dandongadale Yarrarabula Creek fire was started on Thursday by lightning.

The latest advice as of midday Saturday is that the fire is not threatening communities, but those in the area should keep updated.

Overnight strong North-West winds increased the spread and size of the fire to approximately 600 hectares.

The fire is producing large columns of smoke. Forest Fire Management Victoria firefighters, bulldozers and aircraft are working to contain the fire to remote country south of Mt Buffalo.

Forest tracks in the area to the south of Mt Buffalo remain closed to the public.

Forecast weather issued by the Bureau of Meteorology indicates that over the next 24 hours wind speeds are predicted to increase with up to 70km/h over the fire and surrounding areas.

Winds at this strength can be damaging and bring down trees or branches and spread smoke over a large distance from the fire.

The following tracks will be closed to the public:

Campers in the Buckland Valley, including Ah Youngs Campsite and on Mt Buffalo at Lake Catani may see smoke from this Bushfire.

Forest Fire Management Victoria urge all forest users to avoid these areas.

Smoke will be visible from Bright, Wandiligong, Buckland, Mt Buffalo, Lake Buffalo and Abbeyards communities.

urn:contentItem:3S94-9P60-0048-T12T-00000-00<published>1998-03-23T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:26:27Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>Western Australian Regional; Overseas News</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>ASIA: FOREST FIRE ROARS THROUGH THAI NATIONAL PARK</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">BANGKOK, Thailand, March 23 AP - Hundreds of firefighters struggled today to contain a forest fire that has been raging for a week through a national park, threatening wildlife and residents.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> The blaze at the Khao Yai National Park, 190 kilometres northeast of Bangkok, was being whipped along by gusty winds and has consumed thousands of hectares of tinder-dry scrub and trees, officials said.</p><p>Rare animals, including tigers, have headed to higher ground to escape the heat and smoke, the Bangkok Post newspaper reported. Villagers near the park have allegedly been trying to shoot fleeing animals for food.</p><p> Local residents have moved out of the park or have joined the 800 people battling the blaze as volunteers, including at least one Buddhist monk.</p><p> Fires have been erupting throughout the drought-stricken northeast for several months due to lower-than-expected rainfall. The fire season typically peaks in March and April, Thailand's hottest months.</p><p> Firefighters at Khao Yai were encircling the blaze with firebreaks, hoping to at least contain it if they could not put it out. The extremely rugged terrain has hampered efforts to battle the fire, even with aircraft.</p><p> Lack of water and firefighting equipment were also hobbling the firefighters.</p><p> Suchart Sankarom, the Khao Yai fire chief, was cited in today's editions of the Bangkok Post as saying that it would take several decades for the forest to recover.</p><p> Suchart said his unit has warned local people to not start fires to clear farmland, saying the risk was to great the flames would get out of control under the current conditions.</p><p>AP  ts<br/></p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">AAPNEW1998</dc:source><dc:identifier identifierScheme="PGUID">urn:contentItem:3S94-9P60-0048-T12T-00000-00</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="productContentSetIdentifier">160586</dc:source><dc:date dateType="last-updated">2016-01-23</dc:date></dc:metadata><wordCount number="274"/><publicationInfo><publicationName>AAP NEWSFEED</publicationName><copyright>Copyright 1998 AAP Information Services Pty. urn:contentItem:5X77-0HK1-F0J6-J3J0-00000-00Preparing for fire season2019-10-09T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:26:27ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 7Preparing for fire seasonTara Cosoleto

EMERGENCY services in central Victoria are expecting fire season conditions to be on par with other years.

Despite a warmer than average start to 2019, Forest Fire Management regional manager Paul Bates said decent rainfall throughout the region in the past few months has helped the situation.

"In central Victoria, we're expecting what we consider a normal or typical fire season," Mr Bates said.

"We've had reasonable winter rain. Forests are now starting to try out particularly as we move into late spring and summer.

"But to the north of Bendigo, there hasn't been much rain and as you go further along the Murray River - around Kerang, Cohuna, and Echuca - those areas are now very dry. Indeed, we have had some small fires up there already this season."

Country Fire Authority operations manager Bill Johnstone said the conditions would vary across the region throughout the summer.

"We've got quite some disparaging differences between the north of the district near Elmore and Goornong to right down in Gisborne where it's still a little green and a bit damp under foot," Mr Johnstone said.

"So it does vary with topography and land use."

Mr Bates said Forest Fire Management has already started planned burns this month, which was on track with previous years.

"We've been doing a lot of work," he said. "We've employed our seasonal project fire fighters and we're having a training camp in St Arnaud in two weeks time to train new people.

"But critically, we've started planned burning this week at local forests as they're starting to dry out.

"We've started a burn in Dargile and also have a burn near Tarnagulla planned. We're also working with Dja Dja Wurrung to do a couple of cultural burns in Victoria, which is really important work too."

Mr Johnston said the CFA was preparing for every possible scenario.

"We will have a summer every year," he said. "We know that. It would be good to have no campaigns and no large fires that really set ourselves and the community back. Ideally, we'd like to have nothing happen at all. But we know that that's simply not going to happen."

The community also needed to take some responsibility, Mr Johnston said.

"The message is fairly routine," he said. "Now is the time to prepare for the summer ahead. So if you need to clean up around your property, do those things.

"Check out the CFA and the DEWLP websites to understand what your responsibilities are. Understand what it is you need to do on extreme fire days.

"Basically, it's about just getting everything ready and in order because we may not be there to help you."

urn:contentItem:5PTJ-B0Y1-JD34-V28P-00000-00Chance to learn more about traditional land management2017-10-21T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:26:27ZLexisNexisSATURDAYPg. 7Chance to learn more about traditional land management

It is hoped the use of traditional Aboriginal burning practices in land and fire management in Victoria will be developed further following a research trip to the United States.

Forest Fire Management Victoria's Bendigo-based assistant chief fire officer, Scott Falconer, has been awarded the Churchill Fellowship from the Lord Mayor's Bushfire Appeal to travel to the US to explore the involvement of indigenous people in land and fire management.

The Department of Environment, Land, Water and Planning will fund someone from the Dja Dja Wurrung community to undertake the trip alongside Mr Falconer.

Mr Falconer said he hoped the trip would help further the use of traditional Aboriginal practices in Victoria.

"I'm looking forward to finding out how traditional burning and other land management practices are being undertaken in America and how Forest Fire Management and Dja Dja Wurrung can apply some of those learnings in Australia to create jobs for indigenous people to work on-country," Mr Falconer said.

This year, FFM Victoria and the Dja Dja Wurrung Clans Aboriginal Corporation collaborated on an initiative believed to be a first in the state for some 170 years: the reintroduction of traditional burning practices to the land.

The first burns were undertaken in May in Maryborough and Whipstick, where an area of land has since been named Djandak Wi, or 'fire country'.

In July, Mr Falconer described the partnership between the government agency and the traditional owners as an example of "walking together".

At the burn at Whipstick, FFM Victoria district planner and Dja Dja Wurrung man Mick Bourke said the return of traditional burning practices would not only heal country, but heal people, bringing back elders who had been forcibly disconnected from country and providing an avenue for younger people to learn traditional knowledge.

The use of traditional practices will sit alongside contemporary fire management practices.

Mr Falconer has worked in fire, forestry and fisheries for more than 20 years, and was appointed Loddon Mallee assistant chief fire officer with Forest Fire Management Victoria in June last year.

The Churchill Trust aims to provide the chance for Australians to travel overseas to conduct research when opportunities are not readily available here, and reward achievements by providing further opportunity to pursue excellence to enrich Australia.

urn:contentItem:5VNX-9T41-F0JP-W2SR-00000-00Fire seasons getting longer2019-03-20T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:26:27ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 7Fire seasons getting longerBy PETER HUNT

FIRE seasons are getting hotter, drier and 130 days longer.

It comes as the subtropical ridge that dominates southern Australia's dry summers fails to move north in autumn and winter.

The ridge blocks the Southern Ocean's rain-bearing cold fronts from reaching our southern shores.

With temperatures hitting the mid to high 30Cs this week, Bureau of Meteorology climate monitoring head Karl Braganza said the trend was clear - southern Australia's fire season had already blown out by about 130 days.

"All over fire-prone regions nationally, there's almost no region where it hasn't extended," Mr Braganza said.

Along the NSW South Coast and East Gippsland, Dr Braganza said the fire seasons were about 112 days earlier - back to the start of spring - and 22 days longer, extending through March.

In the past the BOM would not record Forest Fire Danger Index levels above 25 until late November or December. But Dr Braganza said those levels were now being picked up in August.

Victoria's Emergency Management Commissioner Andrew Crisp said last August's Cape Conran fire and last March's St Patrick's Day fires provided ample evidence of the lengthening fire season.

He said EMV was responding by working nationally and internationally to share firefighting aircraft, equipment and crews.

But he admitted keeping fuel loads down was becoming more challenging for Forest Fire Management Victoria, given the window for planned burns was narrowing.

Dr Braganza said BOM had seen fire seasons slowly lengthening since the middle of last century. "But there was a step-change in 2000, with a possible shift in the weather systems," Dr Braganza said. "The tropics expanded." Global warming is driving air off the equator at a faster rate into the upper atmosphere, where it cools and dries (producing rain over the tropics), before flowing north and south to dump cold dry air on southern Australia's mid-latitudes.

This cold-dry air forms what meteorologists term the subtropical ridge, which normally dominates southern Australia's weather during summer, before contracting north to the subtropics (north of Tamworth) during winter.However the BOM has discovered the subtropical ridge has repeatedly remained firmly down south for longer, blocking winter westerlies and Southern Ocean cold fronts from delivering autumn and winter rain.

urn:contentItem:5PTJ-B0Y1-JD34-V20H-00000-00Chance to learn more about traditional land management2017-10-21T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:26:27ZLexisNexisREAL ESTATEChance to learn more about traditional land management

It is hoped the use of traditional Aboriginal burning practices in land and fire management in Victoria will be developed further following a research trip to the United States.

Forest Fire Management Victoria's Bendigo-based assistant chief fire officer, Scott Falconer, has been awarded the Churchill Fellowship from the Lord Mayor's Bushfire Appeal to travel to the US to explore the involvement of indigenous people in land and fire management.

The Department of Environment, Land, Water and Planning will fund someone from the Dja Dja Wurrung community to undertake the trip alongside Mr Falconer.

Mr Falconer said he hoped the trip would help further the use of traditional Aboriginal practices in Victoria.

"I'm looking forward to finding out how traditional burning and other land management practices are being undertaken in America and how Forest Fire Management and Dja Dja Wurrung can apply some of those learnings in Australia to create jobs for indigenous people to work on-country," Mr Falconer said.

This year, FFM Victoria and the Dja Dja Wurrung Clans Aboriginal Corporation collaborated on an initiative believed to be a first in the state for some 170 years: the reintroduction of traditional burning practices to the land.

The first burns were undertaken in May in Maryborough and Whipstick, where an area of land has since been named Djandak Wi, or 'fire country'.

In July, Mr Falconer described the partnership between the government agency and the traditional owners as an example of "walking together".

At the burn at Whipstick, FFM Victoria district planner and Dja Dja Wurrung man Mick Bourke said the return of traditional burning practices would not only heal country, but heal people, bringing back elders who had been forcibly disconnected from country and providing an avenue for younger people to learn traditional knowledge.

The use of traditional practices will sit alongside contemporary fire management practices.

Mr Falconer has worked in fire, forestry and fisheries for more than 20 years, and was appointed Loddon Mallee assistant chief fire officer with Forest Fire Management Victoria in June last year.

The Churchill Trust aims to provide the chance for Australians to travel overseas to conduct research when opportunities are not readily available here, and reward achievements by providing further opportunity to pursue excellence to enrich Australia.

urn:contentItem:5VMK-VT11-F0J6-J1S8-00000-00Steel spikes in bush tracks hit a nerve2019-03-14T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:26:27ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 15Steel spikes in bush tracks hit a nerveSimone Fox Koob

A number of steel spikes have been discovered hidden on tracks in bushland north-east of Melbourne, angering locals and emergency services who labelled the behaviour "reckless and dangerous".

Police are investigating after the steel spikes, about 10 centimetres long, were found concealed under leaves and bark on the Breakoday Track in the Toolangi State Forest.

Mason Friedl, a carpenter, was camping in the forest over the Labour Day long weekend when two new tyres on the driver's side of his vehicle were punctured.

When he got out of the car to have a look, he found two thick metal spikes that had been hidden under leaves along a 20-metre stretch of the road. Mr Friedl later found two other spikes a short distance away.

He initially believed he had hit sticks "but then I saw [them] ... I thought 'what's going on here?'."

"It's dangerous for everyone out there. If there's a bushfire and a truck is grounded for something like this, it won't make it out," Mr Friedl said, adding he was worried there may be more spikes in the area.

The discovery sparked concern from emergency services because the tracks are managed by Forest Fire Management and are used by fire trucks and other vehicles.

"This reckless and dangerous behaviour poses a significant threat to members of the community who legitimately use forest roads for ... four-wheel driving, trail-bike riding and horse riding," said Aaron Kennedy, assistant chief fire officer for Forest Fire Management Victoria's Hume region.

"It also threatens the safety of our staff as they continue to respond to bushfires and undertake forest management activities."

Wayne Heavey, chief executive of Four Wheel Drive Victoria, labelled the sabotage as irresponsible.

"Tyres puncturing is the least impact we can see. Someone riding a horse, or motorbike - it could impale them," Mr Heavey said.

"The main reason the tracks are there is for emergency vehicle access ... imagine running down the track to help save someone's property, all of a sudden - bang, bang - and the truck can't move. It's ridiculous, nonsensical and stupid."

Crime Stoppers 1800 333 000.

urn:contentItem:6GSP-9MS3-RTDK-W31C-00000-00September 18, 2025: Horses from Autonomous University of Barcelona: A New Asset in Forest Fire Mitigation2025-09-20T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:26:27ZLexisNexisANNOUNCEMENTSSeptember 18, 2025: Horses from Autonomous University of Barcelona: A New Asset in Forest Fire Mitigation

A recent study, involving Boumort Wildland, the Miranda Foundation, the Forest Horses association, and the University of Barcelona (UB), has shown that horses adjust their diets based on breed, environment, and usage. This adaptability enables them to complement other herbivores in sustainable fire prevention efforts, as their grazing helps to reduce fuel loads and preserve open landscapes. The research was co-authored by UAB's Department of Animal and Food Science researchers Jordi Bartolome and Araceli Gort-Esteve. "Until now research on extensive herding and forest fire prevention has focused mainly on sheep and goats, with some isolated studies done on breeds of rustic cattle. There have been very few studies on horses within this context, since traditionally they are classified as plant grazers that have little effect on woody vegetation," explains Ariadna Nieto-Espinet, a Ramon y Cajal researcher at the UdL and zooarchaeologist. "Our work is one of the first to use empirical data to analyse their potential in forest management in the Mediterranean," she adds.

urn:contentItem:5N71-VCY1-F0J6-J420-00000-00Bushfire fuel to go up in smoke2017-04-02T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:26:27ZLexisNexisBushfire fuel to go up in smoke

Forest Fire Management Victoria has advised central Victorian residents they might see smoke this week with a number of fuel reduction burns planned.

If conditions are suitable on Tuesday, April 4, a 181 hectare burn will take place in the St Arnaud South State Forest.

The burn will be at St Arnaud-Horse Paddock Road, four kilometres south of St Arnaud, and west of the Sunraysia Highway.

A 78 hectare fuel reduction burn will be lit in the Harvest Home State Forest on Tuesday, four kilometres north of Dunolly.

The burn will be west of the Dunolly-Rheola Road, at Dunolly-Old Lead Reservoir.

Forest Fire Victoria has advised Maryborough, Dunolly, Wedderburn, Chewton, St Arnaud, Graytown and Redcastle residents they might see smoke as a result of fuel reduction burns.

"We're working with the Bureau of Meteorology and will only ignite the burns if conditions are suitable," Murray Goldfields district manager Paul Bates said.

Fuel reduction burns aim to reduce the speed and intensity of future bushfires, alongside other fuel management works such as clearing, mowing and slashing.

"This is important work because smaller and less intense fires have less chance of growing to a size that will cause damage to communities and property," Mr Bates said.

He said planned burns were carried out by experienced Forest Fire Management Victoria firefighters, under carefully managed conditions.

"The fuel reduction burns can only go ahead when the weather conditions are suitable, so plans can change," Mr Bates said.

For the latest information about when planned burns are happening near you go to www.ffm.vic.gov.au/plannedburn, download the VicEmergency app or call the VicEmergency hotline on 1800 226 226.

You can also access the Planned Burn Notification System (PBNS) from there, which is an opt-in system that can send you an SMS or email message prior to a burn being carried out and when it is in progress.

urn:contentItem:3S25-D1F0-0048-T548-00000-00<published>1998-02-19T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:26:28Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>Nationwide General News; Overseas News</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>INDONESIA TO PROVIDE US$3.6 MLN FOR FOREST FIRE PREVENTION</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">ll <emphasis typeStyle="it">d</emphasis></p><p nitf:lede="true">im</p><p nitf:lede="true">JAKARTA, Feb 19 Asia Pulse - The Forestry Ministry is providing US$3.6 million for forest fire prevention throughout Indonesia, obtaining the money from the state budget as well as foreign aid, Forestry Minister Djamaluddin Suryohadikusumo said.</p><p nitf:lede="true"><emphasis typeStyle="it"> He did not divulge the fund amount. </emphasis></p><p>The ministry has also provided fund reserve the reforestation of burned down forests, he told the press yesterday.</p><p> He noted that East Kalimantan has seen the worst forest fires.  During the day time of February 13 this year, there<br/> were still approximately 200 fire points in the area. Report received at night on the same day, the fire points had become 462. The following day it increased to 600 and the last report received there were already 859 fire points.</p><p> The minister has warned the rainy season will be very short this year.  The dry season still goes on to March or April.<br/> "The rainy season will start in May. I have to  bring this to<br/> mind for the adjustment of cultivation in the season to come. The dry season will be returning in July," Djamaluddin pointed out.</p><p> In trying to squash the forest fires, if possible the government will create rain by seeding the clouds, he said. The ministry also is using conventional equipment donated by China, Norway and Japan. "We have just received them yesterday," Djamaluddin said.</p><p> (ANTARA)</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">AAPNEW1998</dc:source><dc:identifier identifierScheme="PGUID">urn:contentItem:3S25-D1F0-0048-T548-00000-00</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="productContentSetIdentifier">160586</dc:source><dc:date dateType="last-updated">2016-01-23</dc:date></dc:metadata><wordCount number="233"/><publicationInfo><publicationName>AAP NEWSFEED</publicationName><copyright>Copyright 1998 AAP Information Services Pty. urn:contentItem:5N69-6131-F0J6-J4N3-00000-00Planned burn in Little Desert National Park2017-03-23T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:26:27ZLexisNexisPlanned burn in Little Desert National Park

HORSHAM, Dimboola, Nhill, Kaniva, Natimuk and Goroke, and visitors to the Little Desert National Park have been advised that planned burns will continue on Thursday.

The Department of Environment Forest Fire Management and Parks Victoria will carry out the burns if weather conditions permit in the National Park's central block southern break.

The burns will kick off Forest Fire Management's autumn planned burning program in the Wimmera.

Forest Fire Management Wimmera acting district Manager Glenn Rudolph said a Southern Break Track burn, about 8 km north of Goroke, will be the first of several similar burns to be carried out within the Little Desert National Park over the next three months.

"These edge and internal break burns are conducted along the edges and within small, defined sections of the park to create strategic firebreaks," he said.

"Like all Mallee bush landscapes, the Little Desert National Park is particularly fire-prone.Potentially, large and intense wildfires can burn thousands of hectares and dramatically affect the vegetation and wildlife habitats.

"Edge break burning is designed to reduce fuel to lessen the spread and intensity of bushfires originating in the Little Desert National Park, burning wildlife habitat and escaping into surrounding agricultural communities."

Mr Rudolph said one species that will benefit from this type of burning is the threatened Malleefowl, which relies on long unburnt habitat for breeding.

Smoke from the Little Desert National Park burning program may be visible along the Wimmera Highway/Natimuk-Frances Road to the south; along Nhill-Yanac Road/Western Highway to the north; and from all surrounding townships such as Horsham, Dimboola, Nhill, Kaniva, Natimuk and Goroke.

"During planned burning, the safety of firefighters and the public is our highest priority," Mr Rudolph said.

"We take all possible precautions to ensure people do not enter areas where planned burns are occurring or where a planned burn has recently been conducted until the area is safe."

Access to walking tracks, car parks, camping grounds and picnic sites in the areas close to or in burn areas may be restricted.

Signs may be in place to slow traffic and road travel may be hazardous due to low visibility associated with smoke.

Drivers are advised to obey all traffic signs and instructions from fire crews near the burn.

Residents are advised to close windows and doors to prevent smoke from entering and avoid hanging washing out.

Forest Fire Management has advised to stay clear of areas where burns are taking place or in areas that have recently been burned.

If you are experiencing any symptoms that may be due to smoke exposure, the Department of Health advises that you should seek medical advice or call Nurse on Call on 1300 606 024.

For park closures, please refer to Parks Victoria on 13 19 63 or visit parkweb.vic.gov.au and for travel times and roadworks, visit traffic.vicroads.vic.gov.au.

urn:contentItem:5S7P-GDC1-F0J6-J4KC-00000-00Bushfire in Halls Gap contained2018-05-04T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:26:27ZLexisNexisBushfire in Halls Gap containedAlice Rennison

Both bushfires in Halls Gap have been contained.

They were marked as safe at 1.22 pm.

The bushfire located one kilometre north of Halls Gap has been contained.

Three vehicles are still attending to the bushfire on Grampians Road Halls Gap, which is still out of control.

Halls Gap Police said while the location of the fire was difficult for the CFA and Forest Fire Management Victoria to access, the fire was slow moving.

Halls Gap Police said there are no concerns for public safety and property damage.

"The CFA said it is a slow moving fire and has only burned two hectares,' Halls Gap Police Station Senior Constable Kelly Harris said.

The CFA and Forest Fire Management Victoria are attending to an out of control bushfire in Halls Gap.

There are currently nine CFA vehicles one kilometre north of Halls Gap and six CFA vehicles on Grampians Road Halls Gap attending to the bushfire.

"A private burn off escaped into the national park" which has caused the bushfire, CFA operations manager of CFA district 17 Bernie Fradd said.

"There will be smoke in the area over the day."

Mr Fradd said the conditions are mild, which will hopefully work in the CFA's favour.

"But the next hour is critical," Mr Fradd said.

Mr Fradd also said "for the past few days the CFA has been run off our feet because of out of control burns.

"The conditions are still really dry.

"If you don't have to absolutely burn, please wait until we get some rain."
